FRIDAY. APRIL 22, 1988
We - annotoveremphaaize
the importance of such a
A New Louncil
change. Its necessity, for instance, was again demon'
strated this week when the
council announced that it
has returned once more to a program of compulsory
assemblies. The correctness of this policy does not concern us at the moment. What seems to us of far greater
seriousness is the manner in which it was adopted. The
council has simply presented the campus with a fait
accompli. That sort of star chamber proceeding is all
too common.
There has been a great deal of talk around here lately
about the right of so-called "secret" organizations to
conduct open meetings and assemblies on this campus.
Last winter, for example, the Young Communist league
was denied that right. Persons with long memories
might recall that, until the decision was announced,
there_was no indication that the council was even
Y C 'a ola—rTo-ul.Q.r .ackAamnibLv.Feivr
re picked. We can't, under the circumstances,
imagine any underground revolutionary activity within
the Y C L's capacity, which would make it any more
inimical to the public weal than, is the student council
when functioning by ukase.
One ot
correspondenit'Weity..g elsewhere in thiii
issue, speaks of the "grand council of Fascism." That
is ridiculous. The men now sitting on the council have
no pretensions to dictatorship. In almost every case they
are highly competent for their present offices. Their
only fault is a certain deficiency 4f honest faith in the
democratic process.
We become every day more convinced that, in the
end, the truth will out. If the campus doesn't like the
council's assembly program,. then all the coercion in
the world won't make it successful. And, it will take
more than one evasive decision to quiet the unrpt
stired up by the case of the Young Communist league.
The fundamental evil lies, not in the men, but in the
system. What we need is not just representatives who
combine the best qualities of Alexander Hamilton and
Thomas Jefferson. So long as they function along lines
laid down by the Klu Klux Klan, any talk about popukr democracy is pure balderdash.
And, men who aspire to elective offices have got
to stop cheating their public. It is only fit and right that
the campus should know what its leaders think. The,
time has come to put an end to this business of picking
student council by ear.

and more
adherents, abroad, on the
college ,campus increasing
numbers of students take
part in the annual one-hour
strike against war. Its backing increases each year, of
course, due to the senseless horror raging in Spain and
China. But the advocates of peace disagree painfully on
ways and means.
Fascism Means War is a slogan of a leftist group in
this country that rings truer as the months pass. Japan
in Manchuria, Italy in Ethiopia, Italy and Germany in
Spain, Japan in China, Germany in Austria, all but the
last (which was a little less difficult foi Hitler than our
seizing of Cuba would be) bring to mind impressions of
cowardly pilots of civilization. Truly, an approach to
the problem of keeping war from spreading is necessary, though complex.
Advocates of genuine collective security among democratic and non-aggressive nations have had severe setbacks at home and abroad during the last few years.
And a near death blow to their hopes of a realistic stif- its ultimate importance.
Pure pacifism isn't quite
fening of resistance against warmongers has occurred enough.

With France, still at Britain's apron strings seeking
friendship with II Duce, and Brother Roosevelt giving
the affair his blessing, consideration of collective action appears futile until such policies of our fellow'
democracies are repudiated at the polls.
We hope that the Hopkins Peace Strike goes on record as advocating the carrying out of an educational
campaign, to study, among other things, the object
lessons of prestige—how England has loot moral leadership of other peaceful nations by its policy of giving
in to the forces of Fascism on every important issue,
protesting their actions with sickening promptness and
ineffectiveness, and how Mussolini revived the confidence of his people by winning Ethiopia.
The one thing that stands out most prominently in
international affairs at this moment is the all-pervading
sense of resignation to the calastrophe. The student
strike is important because it simply refuses to recognize
the need for such resignation. It is a gallant challenge
to the imminence of disaster; and such a spirit even if it
fails is never entirely futile.
But the peace strike committee and those who follow
it should not stop at mere gallantry. They should give
their chief consideration to a concrete program to safeguard world peace. Only, in such a prograni, can we

A New Louncil
change. Its necessity, for instance, was again demon'
strated this week when the
council announced that it
has returned once more to a program of compulsory
assemblies. The correctness of this policy does not concern us at the moment. What seems to us of far greater
seriousness is the manner in which it was adopted. The
council has simply presented the campus with a fait
accompli. That sort of star chamber proceeding is all
too common.
There has been a great deal of talk around here lately
about the right of so-called "secret" organizations to
conduct open meetings and assemblies on this campus.
Last winter, for example, the Young Communist league
was denied that right. Persons with long memories
might recall that, until the decision was announced,
there_was no indication that the council was even
Y C 'a ola—rTo-ul.Q.r .ackAamnibLv.Feivr
re picked. We can't, under the circumstances,
imagine any underground revolutionary activity within
the Y C L's capacity, which would make it any more
inimical to the public weal than, is the student council
when functioning by ukase.
One ot
correspondenit'Weity..g elsewhere in thiii
issue, speaks of the "grand council of Fascism." That
is ridiculous. The men now sitting on the council have
no pretensions to dictatorship. In almost every case they
are highly competent for their present offices. Their
only fault is a certain deficiency 4f honest faith in the
democratic process.
We become every day more convinced that, in the
end, the truth will out. If the campus doesn't like the
council's assembly program,. then all the coercion in
the world won't make it successful. And, it will take
more than one evasive decision to quiet the unrpt
stired up by the case of the Young Communist league.
The fundamental evil lies, not in the men, but in the
system. What we need is not just representatives who
combine the best qualities of Alexander Hamilton and
Thomas Jefferson. So long as they function along lines
laid down by the Klu Klux Klan, any talk about popukr democracy is pure balderdash.
And, men who aspire to elective offices have got
to stop cheating their public. It is only fit and right that
the campus should know what its leaders think. The,
time has come to put an end to this business of picking
student council by ear.

Although the cause lof

and more
adherents, abroad, on the
college ,campus increasing
numbers of students take
part in the annual one-hour
strike against war. Its backing increases each year, of
course, due to the senseless horror raging in Spain and
China. But the advocates of peace disagree painfully on
ways and means.
Fascism Means War is a slogan of a leftist group in
this country that rings truer as the months pass. Japan
in Manchuria, Italy in Ethiopia, Italy and Germany in
Spain, Japan in China, Germany in Austria, all but the
last (which was a little less difficult foi Hitler than our
seizing of Cuba would be) bring to mind impressions of
cowardly pilots of civilization. Truly, an approach to
the problem of keeping war from spreading is necessary, though complex.
Advocates of genuine collective security among democratic and non-aggressive nations have had severe setbacks at home and abroad during the last few years.
And a near death blow to their hopes of a realistic stif- its ultimate importance.

fening of resistance against warmongers has occurred enough.

With France, still at Britain's apron strings seeking
friendship with II Duce, and Brother Roosevelt giving

democracies are repudiated at the polls.
We hope that the Hopkins Peace Strike goes on record as advocating the carrying out of an educational
campaign, to study, among other things, the object
lessons of prestige—how England has loot moral leadership of other peaceful nations by its policy of giving
in to the forces of Fascism on every important issue,
protesting their actions with sickening promptness and
ineffectiveness, and how Mussolini revived the confidence of his people by winning Ethiopia.
The one thing that stands out most prominently in
international affairs at this moment is the all-pervading
sense of resignation to the calastrophe. The student
strike is important because it simply refuses to recognize
the need for such resignation. It is a gallant challenge
to the imminence of disaster; and such a spirit even if it
fails is never entirely futile.
But the peace strike committee and those who follow
it should not stop at mere gallantry. They should give
